key_points: Melissa DeRosa, top aide to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, resigned amid sexual harassment allegations against Cuomo.
The resignation occurred less than a week after a report by the state attorney general found Cuomo sexually harassed 11 women.
DeRosa cited her service to New Yorkers as the 'greatest honor of her life' and made no mention of Cuomo in her departure statement.
Her resignation came before a Judiciary Committee meeting that could set a timeline for Cuomo's potential impeachment.
The state attorney general’s report, where DeRosa was mentioned, described a 'toxic' workplace and Cuomo’s alleged harassment and retaliation.
Cuomo has denied allegations of inappropriate behavior and advances toward women.
DeRosa was implicated in efforts to discredit Cuomo’s accuser, Lindsey Boylan, including leaking personnel records.
Sean Hecker, attorney, stated DeRosa consulted experienced counsel regarding the handling of complaints and personnel records.
DeRosa previously faced criticism for her role in underreporting Covid-19 deaths in nursing homes.
Attorney General Letitia James' report found New York underreported nursing home Covid-19 deaths by about 50%.
